metadata.titleEn: One belt, one road, the human development index (1990-2019)
metadata.description: 1) the Human Development Index (HDI - the Human Development Index) to measure the level of the member states of the United Nations economic and social Development indicators, is the result of the GNP Index challenge to traditional;2) this data comes from the United Nations development programme (UNDP) statistical data;3) from the dynamic human development index to reflect the development status of human, reveals the priority to the development of a country, the development policies for countries all over the world especially in developing countries have provided the certain basis, thereby helping to excavate a country's economic development potential;4) data covers all the way "area" 64 1 countries along the (Chinese), 1990-2019, a total of 29 data, in the heart of the "One Belt And One Road" related research application is very broad.
metadata.instructions:
The name of the human development index document is "silkrad"_ HDI(1990-2019).xls"
The data can be read and used by Excel software.

literatureList.titleEn: Effect of the Municipal Human Development Index on the results of the 2018 Brazilian presidential elections
literatureList.referenceEn: Yero, E.J.H., Sacco, N.C., & Nicoletti, M.D.C. (2020). Effect of the municipal human development index on the results of the 2018 Brazilian presidential elections. Expert Systems with Applications, 168, 114305.

literatureList.titleEn: Creation and validation of a socioeconomic development index: A case study on the countries in the Belt and Road Initiative
literatureList.referenceEn: YOU Zhen,SHI Hui, FENG Zhiming, YANG Yanzhao. 2020. Creation and validation of a socioeconomic development index: A case study on the countries in the Belt and Road Initiative. JOURNAL OF CLEANER PRODUCTION,258(2020)120634.

background: The increased polarization on the Brazilian political scene was at its peak on the 2018 general elections. One such indicator is the Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI), a metric for the level of development and quality of life of a municipality. MHDI is derived from the Human Development Index (HDI), a global indicator which is one of the most widely accepted metrics for representing the development status of a country. Like the HDI, the MHDI is composed by three sub-indices: (1) MHDI Education, (2) MHDI Income and (3) MHDI Longevity that, together, offer a detailed view about the development status of a municipality. Conventional knowledge in Brazil states that left-wing parties are the preferred choice for voters residing in less developed regions, where basic needs in education, sanitation, health and food remain unmet, while centrist and right-wing parties tend to be preferred by voters residing in more developed regions, where basic needs usually have been met and the main concerns revolve around employment, security and economic development.
research objective: The objective of this paper is to empirically examine this hypothesis by using population size, MHDI and all its sub-indices as potential predictors of the election results on each municipality.
challenges: To our knowledge, there is no published work regarding the prediction of presidential election results in Brazil, particularly using the development status of each municipality as a potential predictor of election outcomes.
methods: To achieve our main goal, we employed six different supervised classification algorithms to predict the winner of the election on each municipality. As potential predictors, we used the MHDI general index, each of its three sub-indices (education, income and longevity) and the population size of the municipality.
dataset: MHDI and all its sub-indices are calculated based on Brazilian census data, which is publicly available.
findings: The results reached 87% of accuracy when using the education and income sub-indices as predictors of the elections. Based on the results obtained, we were able to confirm that municipalities with higher values for education and income sub-indices overwhelmingly preferred the right-wing candidate, while the left-wing option was preferred by those with lower values of the same sub-indices.

Verification.Question: Does the Human Development Index (HDI) dataset for the '一带一路' countries include data from 1990 to 2019?

Disjunctive.Question: Are the methods used to predict election results in municipalities more often based on supervised classification algorithms, unsupervised learning, or heuristic approaches?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the strategies used to address missing data in datasets related to the Human Development Index across '一带一路' countries?
Where is the data for calculating the Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI) typically sourced from?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to address missing data in human development indices for the countries along the Belt and Road Initiative?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using existing statistical data from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and employing techniques like literature review, data fitting, and regression to address and fill in missing data for the Human Development Index for countries along the Belt and Road Initiative.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that correlates development indices with electoral outcomes in a specific region?
Example.Answer: An example dataset is the Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI) of Brazil, which includes sub-indices for education, income, and longevity, derived from Brazilian census data, and is used to analyze correlations with electoral outcomes in municipalities.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a challenge faced when using a development index as a predictor in political analysis?
Example.Answer: An example challenge is the lack of published work that predicts presidential election results using the development status of each municipality as a predictor, which involves overcoming methodological gaps and ensuring accurate classification in political analysis.

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes of municipal development are captured by the Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI), and how do these attributes aid in analyzing political or election outcomes?

Quantification.Question: Over how many years does the HDI dataset for the '一带一路' initiative provide data?

Definition.Question: What is meant by '查漏补缺' in the context of developing datasets for international indices?
Definition.Answer: '查漏补缺' means identifying and addressing gaps in the dataset by finding missing data or information, which involves using methods like literature review and data modeling to ensure comprehensive coverage of the '一带一路' countries.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method for the Human Development Index (HDI) in '一带一路' countries compare to the methods used for calculating the Municipal Human Development Index (MHDI) in Brazil?
Comparison.Answer: The HDI data for '一带一路' countries is derived from the United Nations Development Programme's statistics, and missing data is supplemented through literature review and statistical methods like fitting and regression. In contrast, the MHDI in Brazil is calculated based on publicly available Brazilian census data, with a focus on sub-indices for education, income, and longevity.

Interpretation.Question: What inferences can be made about the impact of missing data on the reliability and comprehensiveness of development indices across '一带一路' countries, and how might data fitting and regression techniques mitigate these impacts?
Interpretation.Answer: Missing data can reduce the reliability and comprehensiveness of development indices, potentially leading to biased or incomplete assessments of economic and social development across '一带一路' countries. Data fitting and regression techniques can help mitigate these impacts by estimating missing values, allowing for a more complete dataset that can better inform analysis and decision-making.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of additional socio-economic factors, beyond the traditional sub-indices of education, income, and longevity, enhance the predictive accuracy of development indices in assessing regional development variations?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating additional socio-economic factors could provide a more nuanced understanding of regional development variations, potentially enhancing the predictive accuracy of development indices. Such factors might include health infrastructure, employment rates, or access to technology, which could offer deeper insights into the complexities of development beyond the traditional sub-indices.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for additional data collection and analysis when compiling the Human Development Index for countries along the Belt and Road Initiative?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for additional data collection and analysis arises from partial data gaps in the statistics published by the United Nations Development Programme. To address these gaps, researchers must engage in literature review and apply data fitting and regression techniques to provide comprehensive coverage for the 64+1 countries along the Belt and Road Initiative from 1990 to 2019.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges arise from using the Municipal Human Development Index as a predictor for election outcomes in Brazilian municipalities?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise due to the novelty of using the development status of municipalities as predictors for election outcomes, with no prior work having been published in this specific context. The complexity of modeling election outcomes based on socioeconomic indicators like the Municipal Human Development Index and its sub-indices presents methodological difficulties that require careful consideration and validation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of multiple data fitting and regression techniques impact the accuracy and reliability of the '一带一路'沿线国家人类发展指数 over the years?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of various data fitting and regression techniques can improve the accuracy and reliability of the dataset by addressing data gaps and inconsistencies, leading to a more robust temporal analysis of human development trends.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the HDI sub-indices for education, income, and longevity be effectively integrated into machine learning models to predict political outcomes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The HDI sub-indices for education, income, and longevity can be integrated into machine learning models by using them as potential predictors within supervised classification algorithms. These indices provide a detailed view of development status, which can be leveraged to predict outcomes, such as election results, by analyzing how different development dimensions correlate with political preferences.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What data collection techniques are best suited for compiling a comprehensive dataset of Human Development Index metrics for cross-country comparisons along the '一带一路' initiative?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To compile a comprehensive dataset of Human Development Index metrics for cross-country comparisons, it is effective to use publicly available census data, complemented by data collection techniques such as literature reviews and statistical data fitting. This ensures that the dataset captures a broad and accurate representation of development indicators across different countries involved in the '一带一路' initiative.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of sub-indices within the Human Development Index enable more detailed analyses of socioeconomic development in '一带一路' countries?
Enablement.Answer: The use of sub-indices within the Human Development Index, like those for education, income, and longevity, enables detailed analyses by providing a comprehensive view of the development status, allowing for nuanced exploration of trends and disparities in socioeconomic factors.

Expectation.Question: What reasons could contribute to the difficulties in using the Human Development Index as a predictor for political election outcomes in municipalities?
Expectation.Answer: Difficulties could stem from the lack of published work using the development status of each municipality as a predictor, and the necessity of employing various supervised classification algorithms to assess the relationship between HDI and election results.

Expectation.Question: How might data collection methods for the Human Development Index differ when accounting for socio-economic and political variables in '一带一路' countries?
Expectation.Answer: Data collection methods may need to incorporate additional socio-economic and political variables, requiring nuanced fitting and regression techniques to manage incomplete data and potential expansions of the '一带一路' initiative.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential challenges in expanding a dataset to cover more countries along the '一带一路' initiative, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The potential challenges in expanding a dataset to cover more countries along the '一带一路' initiative include dealing with missing data, ensuring data consistency across different countries, and adapting to changes in the political or economic landscapes of these regions. These challenges might be addressed by using statistical methods such as data imputation and regression to fill gaps, collaborating with international organizations for standardized data collection, and continuously updating the dataset as new information and territories become relevant.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the role of literature review and data fitting techniques in enhancing the completeness and accuracy of a dataset, especially for regions with initially sparse data?
Judgmental.Answer: Literature review and data fitting techniques play a crucial role in enhancing the completeness and accuracy of a dataset, particularly for regions with sparse data. These techniques allow researchers to identify and fill data gaps by extrapolating from existing information and leveraging insights from previous studies. By doing so, they improve the dataset's reliability and usefulness for analysis, although they also introduce the need for careful validation to ensure the integrity of the extrapolated data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the Human Development Index data is adapted for different regions, like municipalities versus entire countries.
Assertion.Answer: The MHDI adapts the HDI to a municipal level by incorporating sub-indices for education, income, and longevity, offering a detailed view of development status specific to smaller regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and elaborate on different data collection techniques used to fill the gaps in human development index data for the '一带一路' countries from 1990 to 2019.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset was derived from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) statistical data and included efforts to address missing data through literature review and data fitting, regression, and other processing steps.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding the human development index dataset to include more countries along the '一带一路' initiative, considering future expansions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset can be expanded to include more countries by continuously increasing data coverage as the scope of the '一带一路' initiative grows, ensuring that new regions are incorporated into existing collection and analysis frameworks.
